messageBody:
Hi Venky!


> Why should i go for JUnit testing Framework which i
> can accompolish in plain java class.?
> See what ever i am writing inside a test case funtion
> , i can write it in a plain java class which doesn't
> extend TestCase class?
There is no must to using JUnit, but if you did, things are going
to be a lot easier.

I believe the best part of the Unit Testing Framework is that
the tests are automated, and you can run all your tests whenever
you want(eg. after you made a slight change in your source code).

If you make your own testing classes, in order to do the same
thing, you have to run each of them one by one. Of course,
you might have made a batch script to run all of your tests.
But JUnit already has those features(ie. TestSuites)! Why make
something that's already available? The next good part is that
all of this is easily done.

cf. http://www.extremeprogramming.org/rules/unittests.html


> For example if i want to write a testcase for an EJB i
> have to write a lookup initialisation function in
> setUp() method....and write a test case function for
> each test behaviour...right?
> This i can accomoplish using plain java class which
> can execute different user defined function!!!!
You have to write a lookup initialisation sequence in your
original test class also, wrong? I don't see why writing a
setUp() method would be a pain in the neck. All you have to
do is split your testing method into 3 pieces. (By this I
mean setUp(), testXxx() and tearDown().)

Let's say you wanted to test two methods in a certain class.
And those methods shouldn't be called with the same instance.
Of course, you can instance it twice, but if you do this in
your setUp(), you don't have to worry about those things.
On the contrary, if you want to test one method after the
other has been executed, all you have to do is put them on
the same testing method.


Good luck!
